title: How to find the convergence of $n\sin n.$ (real analysis, calculus, math) - Quora

response.answer_text: I understand you are trying to find the limit of the sequence n/sin(n) when n->inf Consider a subsequence n’/sin(n’) where n’ are all values of n where 2kπ<n<2kπ+π, for all k. This implies that sin(n’)>0 ; hence we may write: n’/sin(n’)>n’, it is easy to see that when n→inf =>n’ →inf, hence n’/sin(n’)→inf. If a subsequence diverges so does the sequence therefore there is not a limit. Furthermore, adopting a similar approach you may define a subsequence with n”/sin(n”), selecting n” so that sin(n”)<0; in this case n”/sin(n”)->-inf….
Once again I do not understand what you are asking, but n/sin n does not tend to 0, so neither it nor its sum converges.
